content: The Dallas Police Department says Officer Amber Guyger's employment has been terminated.

tag: html body main div section article div div div div span
html body main div section article div p span
content: The Dallas Police Department has fired Officer Amber Guyger after she fatally shot a black man in his own home earlier this month.

tag: html body main div section article div p span
content: Guyger told investigators that she shot 26-year-old Botham Jean on Sept. 6 after she mistakenly entered what she believed was her apartment in the same complex and saw someone she thought was a burglar. The incident has raised tensions in Texas, with demonstrators demanding that she be fired.

tag: html body main div section article div p span
content: On Sept. 9, Guyger was arrested and charged with manslaughter, as NPR's Bill Chappell and Barbara Campbell

tag: html body main div section article div p a span
html body main div section article div p span
content: . She posted a $300,000 bond and was quickly released.

tag: html body main div section article div p span
content: After completing an internal investigation, the police department

tag: html body main div section article div p a span
html body main div section article div p span
content: Guyger was "terminated for her actions" during her arrest.

tag: html body main div section article div p span
content: "An Internal Affairs investigation concluded that on September 9, 2018, Officer Guyger, #10702, engaged in adverse conduct when she was arrested for Manslaughter," the police statement read, without providing details. It added that Guyger may appeal her termination.

tag: html body main div section article div p span
content: Guyger had worked for the Dallas Police Department since November 2013. Before she was fired, she "remained on the city payroll on administrative leave,"

tag: html body main div section article div p a span
html body main div section article div p span
html body main div section article div p a span
html body main div section article div p span
content: , lawyers for the victim's family say Guyger's version of events "contradicts accounts from neighbors in the apartment complex."

content: "An affidavit for an arrest warrant says the officer found the door ajar at what she thought was her own apartment," NPR previously reported. "It says it was dark inside, she saw the silhouette of a man, and she gave him orders that he didn't follow."

tag: html body main div section article div p span
content: Guyger said she called 911. Jean died at a local hospital of a gunshot wound to the chest, according to the Dallas County Medical Examiner's office, which ruled his death a homicide.

tag: html body main div section article div p span
content: A lawyer for Jean's family has told local media that two witnesses heard a woman knocking on Jean's door, apparently asking to be allowed into the apartment.
